items.content_html:
Description

Replace the image linked as og:image.

Motivation

We get 40k weekly hits on https://developer.mozilla.org/static/img/opengraph-logo.72382e605ce3.png, which 404s, because opengraph-logo.png has been replaced by mdn-social-share.png.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

See also mdn/translated-content#13501 for the same change in translated-content.
items.title: fix: update og:image

items.content_html:
Description

I added a required="true" attribute in the code snippet.

Motivation

According to theW3C, it is best to add the 'aria-required' property with the value of "true" if users are required to fill out certain sections of a form.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Relates to #26790

items.content_html:
We're flattening the RTCStats hierarchy and making the entry points clearer. This updates RTCStatsReport to include the list of types it might return and information about the map methods.

I have individually documented the map methods. I don't think we can just link to map because the versions in which these are implemented would then not be documentable in the context of RTCStatsReport BCD.

If this gets in, next step would be to purge RTCStats. Then start filling out the other dictionaries.

A question - this is in RTCStatsReport is shown in WebRTC API home page AND https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_Statistics_API -. Is this second doc of any use? It has no sidebar, and I will move most things into RTCStatsReport?
Or to put it another way, how do we handle sidebars with these kind of "sub APIs"

This is part of the docs work in #26146
items.title: RTCStatsReport - make this the center of statistics docs

items.content_html:
Removing ambiguity about the location of index.html

"Fixes #26042"

Suggestions are welcome. I made the change on the basis of the conversation on this ticket.
items.title: Update index.md

items.content_html:
Description

The current docs mention that each embedded browsing context has its own session history.
This PR changes this to emphasize that navigations within iframes (being child navigables) get linearized into a single session history list of the entire traversable navigable (e.g., browser tab).
Reference: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#navigation-and-session-history:child-navigable

Motivation

The user only has a single back/forward interface for traversing the session history via the single session history list of the browser tab. The current docs seem to incorrectly suggest that each embedded browsing controls/maintains its own session history interface.

Additional details

Please refer to https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#navigation-and-session-history for more details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Fix iframe session history description

items.content_html:
Description

I have updated the description on the index page for WebAsembly.Memory to decsribe .buffer how WebAsembly.Memory.prototype.length currently is.

See
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/WebAssembly/JavaScript_interface/Table#instance_properties
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/WebAssembly/JavaScript_interface/Memory#instance_properties

Next, I have added an additional clause regarding how grow() works for shared WebAssembly.Memory instances.

Related issues and pull requests

Holding off until
- #27016
- #27017
items.title: WebAssembly | Memory - homogenise descriptions, and add note about SAB

Add undocumented details from the core specification that were not previous present.

items.content_html:
Description

Allocating WebAssembly.Memory is allowed to sporadically fail should the UA decide to do so or be unable to do so, as per the specification.

Motivation

It conveys the error that may occur if the existing described cases do not apply.

Additional details

From https://webassembly.github.io/spec/js-api/#dom-memory-memory.
items.title: WebAssembly | Memory - add note about allocation failure

items.content_html:

Motivation

The rest of MDN's WebAssembly documentation uses this form of measurment.

Additional details

items.content_html:
Added detail that apply can accept an array-like object and reversed the order of the examples to match the previous order in the sentence.

const numbers = [5, 6, 2, 3, 7];

const max = Math.max.apply(null, numbers);

console.log(max);
// Expected output: 7

const min = Math.min.apply(null, numbers);

console.log(min);
// Expected output: 2

const num2 = {
length: 5,
0: 5,
1: 6,
2: 2,
3: 3,
4: 7,
};

const min2 = Math.min.apply(null, num2);
const max2 = Math.max.apply(null, num2);

console.log(max2);
console.log(min2);

Description

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: clarified distinction between call and apply
